node.text:
We visited India’s perfume capital, Kannauj to see how craftsmen make "attar," or natural perfumes using a centuries-old steam distillation method.

#Perfume #India #StillStanding

node.title: How India's Perfumers Recreate The Smell Of Rain On Earth

node.text:
One of the biggest cargo planes in the world, the C-17 Globemaster III has a payload capacity of 172,000 pounds. The massive plane is used in a variety of missions, including evacuation efforts and troop transport in Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of Kabul in August 2021. This aircraft requires only three crew members to fly: a pilot, a copilot, and a loadmaster. Insider spent three days at Travis Air Force Base, where we observed the training required to fly these giant $340 million feats of engineering. That training included mastering the flight simulator, planning the proper execution of a mission, and then putting that mission into action with an instructor pilot and performing it in the sky.

#bootcamp #airforce #planes #military #pilot

node.title: What it takes to fly the $340 million C-17 Globemaster III | Boot Camp

node.text: Sam Bernstein and April Koh press pause on their busy days as entrepreneurs to reflect on the companies they each founded at a young age. For Bernstein, that was Table22, which helps restaurants create new revenue streams through subscription kits. For Koh, that was Spring Health, which connects employers to mental wellness resources for workers. Their conversation over coffee, thanks to Philips Espresso 3200 LatteGo, reveals a new style of leadership that prioritizes openness and vulnerability and underscores the need to step away and recharge.

node.title: Two young entrepreneurs reflect on the strength that comes from self-care

node.text:
Polaroid was a photographic giant, at one point controlling two-thirds of the instant camera market in the US. As the digital revolution took over, Polaroid was left exposed, and forced to shut down production in 2008. But the company has found new life thanks to the Impossible Project, by bringing Polaroid’s technology into the digital world.

#Polaroid #Photography #Fujifilm #Kodak #Cameras #Photographer

node.title: The rise and fall of Polaroid | Rise And Fall

node.text:
Durian’s smell is famously divisive. But in Asia and the Pacific Islands, durian is known as the “King of Fruit.” Nonthaburi, Thailand, is known for cultivating some of the most sought-after durian varieties: Kan Yao and Mon Thong. In 2019, one Nonthaburi, or Nont, durian sold at auction for $48,000. So, what makes this pungent, spiky fruit so expensive?

#durian #soexpensive #fruit #nonthaburi #thailand #expensive

node.title: Why Nonthaburi durians are so expensive | So Expensive

node.text:
A lavender farm in West Virginia is restoring land destroyed by coal mining and providing jobs in a state struggling as the fossil fuel energy is on its way out. There are over 6 million acres of abandoned coal mines across the US, and more could go to waste if coal companies don’t restore their land.

#WestVirginia #Lavender #CoalMining #RestoringLand #FossilFuel #Coal #Farming #Environment

node.title: Can lavender save land ruined by coal mining? | World Wide Waste

node.text:
From finishing each piece with a glossy shine to cutting down blocks of wood by hand — it takes over 200 artisans to craft just one Steinway grand piano. Steinway is one of the most famous piano brands in the world, and depending on the model, it can be one of the priciest. A Steinway Model D ebony concert piano will cost you $187,000. Famous pianists and music icons like Billy Joel and Lang Lang play on Steinway pianos. But with several other high-end piano brands on the market, why are musicians so drawn to Steinway? And why are these pianos so expensive?

#Steinway #SteinwayandSons #Piano #Music #MusicalInstrument #SteinwayPiano #Musicians

node.title: Why Steinway grand pianos are so expensive | So Expensive

node.text:
Pottery is a traditional industry in Gaza, supported by families like Sabri Atallah's. But decades of armed conflict and political strife have put these artisans' livelihoods at risk. We visited Sabri Atallah & Sons Pottery Factory before, during, and after the May 2021 attacks to see how he is keeping the craft alive.

Sabri only sells his pottery locally and does not have a website.

#Gaza #Israel #Palestine #Pottery #PotteryShop #MakingPottery #Familyrun #PotteryFactory

node.title: How This Pottery Shop Survived Six Decades Of War And Conflict In Gaza

node.text:
Powerful greenhouse gases lurk inside most refrigerators. One recycling company in Guatemala City is working to keep them out of the atmosphere. Its work is partially funded by carbon offset credits, which experts say can help fight the climate crisis but require close scrutiny.

#Guatemala #GreenhouseGases #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #recycle #RecycleFridge #Environment

node.title: Why refrigerators are so hard to recycle | World Wide Waste

node.text:
Before they can begin their training to become Air Assault-qualified, all students at the Sabalauski Air Assault School must survive "day zero," a physically and mentally grueling test that marks the beginning of what's known as the Army's "10 toughest days." Beginning before sunrise, day zero consists of a detailed inspection of the students' gear, a 2-mile run and culminates with an intimidating obstacle course featuring two major events that all students must conquer — otherwise they are dropped from training before phase one begins. On a scorching day in June where the heat index rose to over 100 degrees, Insider followed two students to find out if they have what it takes to survive day zero and move on to day one of Air Assault School.

Located inside the Fort Campbell Army installation on the Tennessee-Kentucky border, the Air Assault School is where students train to insert themselves and equipment into combat using helicopters. 

#AirAssault #AirAssaultSchool #FortCampbell #Army #BootCamp

node.title: What it takes to survive the Army's 'day zero' at Air Assault School

node.text:
Hasselblad cameras have taken some of the most iconic photos of the 20th century. From the first moon landing, to The Beatles crossing Abbey Road, and portraits of Marilyn Monroe. But the company has gained a reputation for having extremely expensive cameras. Hasselblad’s H6D-100c camera costs over $30,000. But its cameras weren’t always this expensive.

#hasselblad #camera #cameraequipment #abbeyroad #marilynmonroe #thebeatles #soexpensive

node.title: Why Hasselblad cameras are so expensive | So Expensive

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows the Golden Gate Bridge in San Fransico. It reads: These are the 28 US cities where managers are the most open to letting their employees keep working remotely after the pandemic

node.text:
Managers in these cities are the most open to long-term remote work post-COVID.

A recent survey from HR consulting firm Robert Half pinned down the 28 US cities where the biggest percentage of managers say they'll let employees work remotely part- or full-time once COVID-19 restrictions are gone. 

In Boston, which led the pack, 45% of managers will let remote work continue once restrictions lift. Click the link in our bio to see the other 21 cities with managers most open to remote work.

Story by Sarah Jackson.

(Credit: Amina Kilpatrick/ Insider, Shutterstock, Getty Images, AP Photo)

A graphic shows freight ships sitting off the coast of California in January with arrows pointing to the ships. The text reads: A record-breaking 44 container ships are stuck off the coast of California

node.text:
Forty-four freight ships are stuck awaiting entry into California's two largest ports, breaking the previous record since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic of 40 ships, the Marine Exchange of Southern California reported on Saturday.

The ports account for about one-third of US imports, serving as a main source of trade with China.
The queue is a result of the labor shortage, COVID-19-related disruptions, and holiday-buying surges. 

Port of Los Angeles data indicated that the ships' average wait time had increased to 7.6 days. 

(Credit: Getty Images)

node.text: How to open a brokerage account and how to buy a stock. We’ll also offer tips for building your portfolio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Under $200K 100% Share of new homes sold by price Over $400K $200K $400K 80% 60% 40% 20% 0% 2002 2008 2014 Source: US Census Bureau via FRED 2020 INSIDER'.

node.text:
In 2002, more than half of new homes sold for under $200,000. In July 2021, less than 2% did, while nearly half sold for over $400,000.

This chart chart shows the death of the American starter home over the last 2 decades. Homeownership has become increasingly unaffordable for the American middle class, and it's getting worse.

(Credit: Taylor Tyson/@bi_graphics)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on August 30, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Premium DENVER $176K SF $207K MIAMI $167K INSIDER There's a battle brewing over salaries for remote workers and it could change the way everyone gets paid'.

node.text:
It's always been the ultimate dream of remote work: living in luxury, somewhere cheap, on a big-city salary. 

But some tech giants have decided to play hardball with employees who want to relocate for good. Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter, Dropbox, and a host of other Silicon Valley mainstays have told their employees that if they move away from pricey cities, they should expect to get their salaries cut — in some cases by as much as 25%.

Click the link in our bio to subscribe to Insider and read the full story on the battle over salaries for remote workers.

Story by Aki Ito.

(Credit: Samantha Lee/Insider)

#remotework #remotejobs #salary #careers #jobs

A graphic shows a man holding a CV while sitting front of a computer. It reads: The 8 key ways to prepare ahead of an online interview, according to recruiters and headhunters

node.text:
With remote rather than face-to-face interviews, there are different factors to consider. Firms are shifting to remote or hybrid models, so it's more likely your interview will be online.

Here are eight tips to help you prepare for a job interview from home. Click the link in our bio to read the full story by Cristina Fernández Esteban and Qayyah Moynihan.

(Credit: Amina Kilpatrick/Insider, Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows a man holding a CV while sitting front of a computer. It reads: The 8 key ways to prepare ahead of an online interview, according to recruiters and headhunters

Text-only graphic reads: 1. Make sure your tech is working. The last thing you need during an online interview is for your laptop or tablet to start playing up.

Before the interview check:
	• The wifi connection.
	• All devices are updated and working quickly.
	• That you have a backup device.
	• You have installed, updated, and know how to use the program on which your interview will be conducted.

Text-only graphic reads: 2. Think about the device you'll use. You need to ensure your battery is charged up enough to last throughout the call and that your device allows you to be heard and seen clearly.

Text-only graphic reads: 3. Go for neutral, well-lit background. Make sure if you have kids, roommates, or pets that you close doors where possible to minimize disturbances.

It's also essential that your room is as neutral and impersonal as possible, otherwise, your interviewer may get distracted and it even give off an unprofessional impression.

Go for a smooth, well-lit background — ideally, try to face natural light to avoid creating shadows or backlights.

Text-only graphic reads: 4. Think about camera positioning. It's good to keep the camera at eye level so that when you look into the screen, it makes the person at the other end feel as though you're addressing them and making eye contact.

It's also important not to forget body language as it can reduce the sense of distance created by the remote setup. Making sure to use hand and arm gestures when you're on-screen will help make the interview feel a lot more natural.

Text-only graphic reads: 5. Dress up. Your goal is to look as professional as possible at all times. 

Forget sweatshirts and don't be tempted to go for smart-up-top while still wearing your pajama pants; dress the same way you would if the interview was face-to-face. 

Try to choose neutral tones (blue, black, and gray are those most recommended by recruiters) and avoid prints and stripes, only as they may appear distorted in the image.

Text-only graphic reads: 6. Bolster your remote working skills. Ensuring you touch upon self-discipline, communication skills, and initiative — all sought-after skills when working remotely — is crucial if you want to impress your prospective employers. 

Make sure to give clear and concise examples of how you've demonstrated your abilities, show interest, and ask sensible questions about the company and the role.

Text-only graphic reads: 7. Practice giving your answers on camera. Make sure to prep the answers to common questions and practice answering them aloud and on camera by recording yourself.

Questions such as:
	• "Why do you want to work here?"  
	• "Think of an obstacle and how you overcame it."

Pay attention to your posture, nervous tics, overusing certain fillers, and what you're doing with your hands.

Text-only graphic reads: 8. Take advantage of the remote setup. The interviewer can't see anything behind the camera or on the table. You can leave notes in front of you just in case you need a bit of help at any stage during the interview process.

Use post-its to note down any relevant data you don't want to forget, questions that might impress the recruiter, or phrases to jog your memory or switch to a different subject if, for whatever reason, you lose your train of thought.

Photo by Business Insider on August 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and text that says 'INSIDER Japan's overworking problem: A probe into 24,000 Japanese workplaces revealed that 37% had violated overtime laws'.

node.text:
Probes by Japanese authorities into overwork complaints at 24,042 workplaces revealed that 37% of these companies had employees working 45 hours a month or more in overtime, the country's Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare reported.

Employers found to violate the laws could face up to six months in prison or fines of up to JP¥300,000 ($2,727).

The ministry's official stats show that the average Japanese employee only took 52.4% of the paid leave they were entitled to in 2018.

Read more of Matthew Loh's story at the link in our bio.

(Credit: Charly Triballeau/AFP via Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on August 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and text that says 'INSIDER Japan's overworking problem: A probe into 24,000 Japanese workplaces revealed that 37% had violated overtime laws'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What the report found Japanese authorities found that nearly 9,000 companies breached overtime laws last year. The ministry also confirmed cases of workers pulling more than 100 hours of overtime work a month in 1,878 workplaces. The federal government has tried to curb overtime pressure with policies like making employers designate days off for workers with unused leave, or giving employees the chance to leave the office at 3 p.m. every last Friday of the month. INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Japanese labor laws Japan officially adopted a 40-hour work week in 1987 and considers anything beyond that to be overtime. Japanese labor laws generally limit overtime to 45 hours a month. However, if a company goes through extraordinary circumstances and its employees agree to work more overtime, they can be granted an extra dispensation to work up to 80 hours of overtime per month. INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Karoshi Japan has ecently been trying to relieve itself of a grueling overtime culture that has persisted for decades. It's so common for Japanese employees to work themselves to death that the country has a term fori karoshi, or literally 'death by overwork." Victims of karoshi were typically middle-aged men in office jobs, but recently, women have made up one in five of such cases, Hiroshi Kawahito, a lawyer, told Reuters. INSIDER'.

Photo shows a mom on her laptop holding a child. It is overlaid with text that reads: "Strategies working moms can use to juggle parenting, family, and everything else, according to experts." There is an arrow indicating the ability to swipe through the post.

node.text:
The pandemic created a childcare crisis, and mothers bore the brunt of the burden.

Some left their jobs, while many others scaled back their careers. Their mental health declined. Roughly 9.8 million working mothers in America suffered from workplace burnout and were 28% more likely to experience burnout than fathers. Cases were even higher among Black, Asian, and Hispanic women.

As the Delta variant surges and the pandemic's second new school season gets underway, working mothers are again bracing for what's in store.
 
There are no easy solutions, but experts say there are concrete steps you can take to ease your burden — or at least the way you think about it — both at home and on the job.

See all 4 expert-recommended strategies at the link in our bio.

Story by Rebecca Knight.

(Credit: Violeta Stoimenova/Getty)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shows a mom on her laptop holding a child. It is overlaid with text that reads: "Strategies working moms can use to juggle parenting, family, and everything else, according to experts." There is an arrow indicating the ability to swipe through the post.

Blue text on a black background reads: "Talk to your partner about the division of labor at home." White text underneath reads: "Just because societal expectations about household work exist doesn't mean they should be the norm in your family, said Lori Mihalich-Levin, the author of 'Back to Work After Baby.'

She and her husband hold weekly planning meetings where they look at their professional obligations, their children's schedules, and household demands and then divide the workload equitably."

Blue text on a black background reads: "Streamline your workday." White text underneath reads: "Start by reducing the number of decisions you need to make. Wake up and go to bed at the same time, routinize your weekly meal plans and grocery shops, and wear a 'uniform,' à la Barack Obama.

Daisy Dowling, the author of 'Workparent,'  also suggested removing any and all time-sucks from your calendar. Bow out of extraneous meetings. Decline unnecessary commitments. Turn off the internet when you're doing work that requires intense focus."

Blue text on a black background reads: "Adopt a long-term mindset about your career." White text underneath reads: "Executive coach Rachel Montañez said a lot of working mothers say 'they feel like they're coasting,' which creates a special type of 'mom guilt' about not being a good enough employee while also not spending more time with their children.

Montañez recommended reframing your approach. 'You may not always be gunning for that next promotion but can be using your talents to develop new skills, cultivate relationships, and mentor others,' she said."

Graphic with the headline: "Wealth for normal Americans compared to billionaires." Underneath, a series of green circles shows comparable degrees of wealth, with the biggest being Tesla CEO Elon Musk, worth $192 billion. The smallest circle, represeting the US avg. wealth of $393,000, is so tiny that there is a second circle around it to highlight it.

node.text:
The gap between normal Americans and the wealthy shouldn't surprise anyone — but just look at this chart and the mind reels.

The bubbles represent the relative wealth of the average American — just one pixel wide — compared to the average wealth of the top 1% of people in the US.

We also threw in bubbles to represent multibillionaires Marc Benioff and Charles Koch, as well as Elon Musk, the richest person in the world as of August 24.

Read more of Bartie Scott and Andy Kiersz's story at the link in our bio.

(Credit: Andy Kiersz/Insider, World Inequality Database, Bloomberg Billionaires Index)

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows two cups of coffee and a small scoop of grounded coffee beans. It reads: The global coffee supply chain is suffering as 2nd-biggest grower Vietnam locks down travel amid renewed virus fears.

node.text:
The global coffee supply chain is suffering as Vietnam — the world's second-biggest grower — imposes a strict travel lockdown. This comes amid renewed fears of a COVID-19 outbreak as fatalities and deaths in the nation spike.

This recent mandate affected some key producing areas of the Central Highlands, Bloomberg reported. This area is also known as the "Kingdom of Coffee," according to local media, as it is home to roughly 570,000 hectares of coffee trees.

Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

(Credit: Shutterstock)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on August 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Premium IDER As Elizabeth Holmes heads to to trial on fraud charges, former Theranos employees empl share new tales about her alleged paranoia, a 'tone deaf' Christmas gift, and demands for utter devotion'.

node.text:
Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes faces up to 20 years in prison if found guilty on fraud charges. Her trial begins August 31.

Former employees are speaking out for the first time about their experiences working at the blood-testing startup.

The ex-CEO "feels wronged, like Salem-witch-trial wronged," a person who worked closely with Holmes told Insider. Click the link in our bio to subscribe to Insider and read the full story.

Story by Melkorka Licea.

(Credit: Getty Images)
#elizabethholmes #elizabbethholmestrial #theranos #theranostrial

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on August 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Premium IDER As Elizabeth Holmes heads to to trial on fraud charges, former Theranos employees empl share new tales about her alleged paranoia, a 'tone deaf' Christmas gift, and demands for utter devotion'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER The trial On July 10, Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of Theranos, gave birth to her first child, William Holmes Evans. But instead of basking in the afterglow of becoming a mother, Holmes is preparing to stand trial on fraud charges. If found guilty, she faces up to 20 years in prison.'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER Theranos machines Holmes' startup promised to revolutionize medical testing. When she founded Theranos, in 2003, she said her blood blood-testing machine could perform numerous complicated tests, including ones that could detect cancer, with just a drop of blood. She was hailed as the next Steve Jobs in a fawning 2015 Inc. cover story and spoke on panels alongside Bill Clinton. But the machines didn't work.'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER Fraud charges And Holmes, prosecutors now say, knew it all along. In 2018, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused Holmes of conducting "an elaborate, years-long fraud," and authorities charged her with two counts of conspiracy to commit wire fraud as well as 10 counts of wire fraud.'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER Former employees Now, on the heels of one of the most anticipated tech trials of all time, set to start August 31, former employees look back at Holmes' Theranos, telling Insider about her infatuation with secrecy and unrelenting belief that their work at Theranos would change the world. Her unconventional requests and expectations like forbidding the use of the word "blood" during interviews- defined many of their experiences.'.

Photo by Business Insider on August 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER Distractions Several of Holmes' associates, including former Theranos employees some of whom are speaking out for the first time- expressed concern that her 7-week-old infant would distract jurors from the crimes she's alleged to have committed. Click the link in our bio to read the full story.'.

We visited India’s perfume capital, Kannauj to see how craftsmen make "attar," or natural perfumes using a centuries-old steam distillation method.

#Perfume #India #StillStanding
